docs.lead_paragraph: When will Wall Street stop springing these types of nasty surprises? Every big bank has risk controls. Teams of executives are assigned to manage and review trades to ensure the bank's safety and health.

headline.main: The Bet That Blew Up For Chase: Risk Management Failed at JPMorgan, As It Has So Often for Others

docs.abstract: JPMorgan Chase's $2 billion trading loss again focuses attention on risk-management lapses at big banks; loss recalls similar disasters at MF Global and UBS, and calls into question whether banks have learned to curb hubris and risk-taking in the wake of the 2008 financial collapse. Photo (M)
docs.snippet: When will Wall Street stop springing these types of nasty surprises?     Every big bank has risk controls. Teams of executives are assigned to manage and review trades to ensure the bank's safety and health.

byline.original: By PETER EAVIS and SUSANNE CRAIG

headline.main: Loss Stains JPMorgan's Chief, One of Banking's Top Risk Managers
headline.print_headline: The Bet That Blew Up For Chase: A Huge Loss Stains Dimon, One of Banking’s Top Risk Managers

docs.abstract: The company’s loss is a rare misstep by Jamie Dimon, who prides himself on having his fingers on the pulse of his 270,000-employee company.

docs.lead_paragraph: To prevent cuts to the Pentagon’s budget, House Republicans have chosen to cut programs that help some of the most vulnerable Americans.
docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes House Republicans for voting to prevent $55 billion in automatic cuts imposed on the Pentagon, choosing instead to make cuts from domestic programs; contends Republicans are determined to protect millionaires and defense contracts, no matter the cost to the country.
docs.snippet: To prevent cuts to the Pentagon’s budget, House Republicans have chosen to cut programs that help some of the most vulnerable Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a quiet realization that American factories need subsidies to survive globally — especially to compete with Asian and European companies that routinely receive government assistance.

headline.seo: Subsidies Aid Rebirth in U.S. Manufacturing
headline.main: Subsidies Aid Rebirth in U.S. Manufacturing
headline.print_headline: What It Takes to Keep a Factory

docs.abstract: American management and labor agree that manufacturing needs help in the form of federal, state and local subsidies, along with labor concessions, for survival in a global economy in which Asian and European companies are routinely subsidized; such support is leading to a rebirth in manufacturing, reflected by a rise in its contribution to the gross domestic product.
docs.snippet: There is a quiet realization that American factories need subsidies to survive globally — especially to compete with Asian and European companies that routinely receive government assistance.

docs.lead_paragraph: In rejecting the online marketplace, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey cited a pending Supreme Court challenge to the Affordable Care Act, but his move was largely symbolic.

headline.seo: Christie Vetoes Health Insurance Exchange for New Jersey
headline.print_headline: Christie Vetoes Insurance Exchange, Citing Supreme Court Case on Health Care Law

docs.abstract: Gov Chris Christie of New Jersey vetoes an online marketplace created by the Legislature to help residents and small businesses buy health insurance, in a swipe at President Obama's signature health care legislation; cites a pending Supreme Court challenge to the Affordable Care Act, which requires most Americans to have health insurance and mandates states to have benefit exchanges.
docs.snippet: In rejecting the online marketplace, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey cited a pending Supreme Court challenge to the Affordable Care Act, but his move was largely symbolic.

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill to trim the deficit — hitting mostly programs for the poor — has no chance of becoming law, but could set the terms of debate in an election year.

headline.seo: House Approves $310 Billion in Cuts; Senate Passage Unlikely
headline.main: House Approves $310 Billion in Cuts, but Passage in the Senate Is Very Unlikely
headline.print_headline: House Approves $310 Billion in Cuts, but Passage in the Senate Is Very Unlikely

docs.abstract: House approves sweeping legislation to cut $310 billion from the deficit over the next decade; plan makes significant cuts to programs for the poor, shifting those savings to the Pentagon to stave off automatic military spending cuts scheduled for 2013; legislation has no chance of passage in the Senate.
docs.snippet: A bill to trim the deficit — hitting mostly programs for the poor — has no chance of becoming law, but could set the terms of debate in an election year.
